sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using LU decomposition
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using LU decomposition, we first need to decompose the given matrix A into a lower triangular matrix L and an upper triangular matrix U.

Matrix A and the vector b are given by:

A = \begin{bmatrix}
    2 & 3 & 1\\
    4 & 2 & 3\\
    3 & 4 & 2\\
\end{bmatrix}

b = \begin{bmatrix}
    13\\
    17\\
    14\\
\end{bmatrix}

Now, let's find the L and U matrices using Doolittle's method:

L = \begin{bmatrix}
    1 & 0 & 0\\
    l_{21} & 1 & 0\\
    l_{31} & l_{32} & 1\\
\end{bmatrix}

U = \begin{bmatrix}
    u_{11} & u_{12} & u_{13}\\
    0 & u_{22} & u_{23}\\
    0 & 0 & u_{33}\\
\end{bmatrix}

Using Doolittle's method, we get:

u_{11} = a_{11} = 2
u_{12} = a_{12} = 3
u_{13} = a_{13} = 1

l_{21} = a_{21} / u_{11} = 4 / 2 = 2
u_{22} = a_{22} - l_{21} * u_{12} = 2 - 2 * 3 = -4
u_{23} = a_{23} - l_{21} * u_{13} = 3 - 2 * 1 = 1

l_{31} = a_{31} / u_{11} = 3 / 2
l_{32} = (a_{32} - l_{31} * u_{12}) / u_{22} = (4 - (3/2) * 3) / (-4) = 1/2
u_{33} = a_{33} - l_{31} * u_{13} - l_{32} * u_{23} = 2 - (3/2) * 1 - (1/2) * 1 = 0

Now we have:

L = \begin{bmatrix}
    1 & 0 & 0\\
    2 & 1 & 0\\
    3/2 & 1/2 & 1\\
\end{bmatrix}

U = \begin{bmatrix}
    2 & 3 & 1\\
    0 & -4 & 1\\
    0 & 0 & 0\\
\end{bmatrix}

Since the U matrix has a row of zeros, the system of equations is singular and does not have a unique solution.
